quotes.topic_title: Career motivation and the “fake rabbit” trap
quotes.text: And what was interesting is the moment that the dogs, if they accidentally touched the rabbit, they would never run again because there was like, "Well, what's next? I've achieved what I was looking for."
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A vivid analogy for how hitting a single milestone can kill motivation if you don’t have a next chapter planned.

quotes.topic_title: Career motivation and the “fake rabbit” trap
quotes.text: So I think this happens a ton, it's like your listeners are spending time focused on like, "Well, one day I will be X. I will be that vice president. I will have more money. I will have built something. I will have started a company." But they don't think about what happens next.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Challenges the common career pattern of optimizing for a single title/goal without designing what comes after it.

quotes.topic_title: Career motivation and the “fake rabbit” trap
quotes.text: What's the second thing? What's your career next look like?
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A practical prompt to turn career planning into a multi-step roadmap rather than a one-time achievement.

quotes.topic_title: Career motivation and the “fake rabbit” trap
quotes.text: How do you ensure that you are always going to have something important and motivating to do with your career?
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to proactively create ongoing sources of meaning and motivation at work.

quotes.topic_title: Career motivation and the “fake rabbit” trap
quotes.text: Otherwise, you'll keep working because you know nothing else to do, but you'll be sadder or you'll find ways to create war when peace is needed.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that lacking a “what’s next” can lead to self-sabotage and unnecessary conflict even amid success.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we cover all aspects of the PM career and what it takes to be successful at every stage of the journey, including the dangers of thinking too short term, the importance of avoiding what he calls ex-growth companies, why you're probably not getting promoted, what to focus on if you're a new manager, the rise of the senior IC path, also why top leaders often have huge development areas they don't know about and how to catch them, and also why people who make it to the top often run into serious mental health challenges.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A dense preview of the episode’s most actionable career themes, including promotion dynamics, leadership blind spots, and mental health risks at the top.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You may not realize this, but your email tools are wasting your time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian prompt to question default tooling and look for leverage in everyday workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Built to work with Gmail and Outlook, teams who use Superhuman spend half the time in their inboxes, respond to twice the number of emails, and save over four hours a week.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete performance claims that quantify potential productivity gains from changing email tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: That's over a month of saved time per year.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that translates weekly time savings into an annual impact practitioners can easily evaluate.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: teams who use Superhuman spend half the time in their inboxes, respond to twice the number of emails, and save over four hours a week.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete productivity benchmarks practitioners can use to evaluate whether an email tool is delivering meaningful ROI.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Superhuman, you can split your inbox into streams for VIPs, team members, and emails from your favorite products to reduce context switching and make sure you never miss an important email.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical workflow pattern (inbox segmentation) to reduce context switching and improve responsiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can start reminders if you don't hear back so that you can follow up and never drop the ball on an email thread.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A simple operational habit—automated follow-up reminders—that prevents dropped threads and improves reliability.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can watch live session replays to discover where users are breezing through your flow and where they struggle.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A direct method for diagnosing UX friction by observing real user behavior rather than relying on assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Stop guessing, get clarity, check out Clarity at clarity.microsoft.com.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable mantra pushing teams from intuition-driven decisions to evidence-driven product iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Mentorship scale and coaching “911 calls”
quotes.text: So now what I do is I tend to help and coach hundreds of folks through transitions.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Highlights a scalable mentorship focus area—career transitions—where coaching can have outsized impact.

quotes.topic_title: Mentorship scale and coaching “911 calls”
quotes.text: So if they're in a moment where they're trying to decide between another job, if they're trying to decide to leave, if they're having sort of an alert at work, I call them 911 calls.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model (“911 calls”) for prioritizing urgent, high-stakes coaching moments.

quotes.topic_title: Mentorship scale and coaching “911 calls”
quotes.text: So I find those are the most substantive times to help people, is when they're in moments of dilemma or forks in the road, and that's why the number is more closer to hundreds.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on when mentorship is most valuable: during dilemmas and decision forks rather than routine check-ins.

quotes.topic_title: Mentorship scale and coaching “911 calls”
quotes.text: Probably half dozen to kind of close to a dozen at this point.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing the downstream impact of his mentorship network (mentees later becoming notable enough to appear on the podcast).

quotes.topic_title: Mentorship scale and coaching “911 calls”
quotes.text: Yeah. We'll keep it anonymous because I want people to feel they can always call me in and not feel like that. I don't tend to share the names of most people.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Emphasizes confidentiality as a mechanism to increase psychological safety and encourage people to seek help when stakes are high.

quotes.topic_title: Early career: avoid short-term career decisions
quotes.text: Lateral moves are by definition not forward moves. So what I try to tell people to think about is work backwards from your end state.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Reframes job switching away from short-term relief toward reverse-planning from a long-term destination.

quotes.topic_title: Early career: avoid short-term career decisions
quotes.text: Almost think of career as a product. So if you're building a good product, you think about, "Well, here's what a great product would look like," and then you break it into version one, version two, version three.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Introduces a product-roadmap mental model for structuring career decisions into iterative “versions.”

quotes.topic_title: Early career: avoid short-term career decisions
quotes.text: I always think about not the next job, but the one after it. Maybe think about not your boss's job but your boss's boss's job and what do I need to think about to get there.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A practical heuristic (“job after next”) for choosing roles that build toward higher-leverage future positions.

quotes.topic_title: Early career: avoid short-term career decisions
quotes.text: I'd say the biggest one in workplace is focusing career and promotion together.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that career progress is synonymous with promotion timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Early career: avoid short-term career decisions
quotes.text: So then I'm like, "Well, okay, then what's the promotion in service of?"
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A diagnostic question to ensure promotions are aligned with a longer-term career arc rather than being an end in themselves.

quotes.topic_title: Logos vs meaningful building and diverse experiences
quotes.text: I'm actually really a big fan of a diverse set of experiences, that I think learning about pre-product market fit then seeing smoke turn into fire and witnessing and maybe shepherding that and then taking fire and turning it into something great and being an experience set where you can see the movie in these different frames makes you just a better builder.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A vivid “movie frames” mental model for deliberately collecting experiences across company stages to become a stronger builder.

quotes.topic_title: Logos vs meaningful building and diverse experiences
quotes.text: So you can't really go wrong if you're looking at those experiences. And you're looking at inside the building problems and outside the building problems, those are maybe consumer problems and business-to-business problems. The more diverse career you have, the better builder you are.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to diversify across problem types (inside/outside the building; consumer/B2B) as a direct path to better building.

quotes.topic_title: Logos vs meaningful building and diverse experiences
quotes.text: But the idea of just doing that because you think it's going to make your chances better for the next job maybe scares me and it feels very much in service of some future dream that is not build oriented. And I think that can be leading to sadness.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that optimizing for resume optics over building can be emotionally costly and misaligned with why builders do the work.

quotes.topic_title: Logos vs meaningful building and diverse experiences
quotes.text: Generically, the answer is yes. I think it's especially important for executives.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A nuanced take: “logos” matter, but disproportionately so at the executive level.

quotes.topic_title: Logos vs meaningful building and diverse experiences
quotes.text: The MAGMA or FAANG companies, however you want to describe them, they really have challenges and expertise at how to build things at scale, how to manage millions or billions of users and customers.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A concrete rationale for big-tech brand value: it signals proven experience operating at massive scale.

quotes.topic_title: Ex-growth companies: definition, risks, and signals
quotes.text: So the two questions you ask yourself the day after we listen to this podcast is, "Hey, are we scaling a product? We have customers that love us and we have a tremendous sucking sound? Or are we trying to find that customer sucking sound?"
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic framework to distinguish scaling with real pull from searching for product-market fit.

quotes.topic_title: Ex-growth companies: definition, risks, and signals
quotes.text: And if the answer is, "We're still trying to find it," and then you're like, "Is your evaluation hundreds of millions or tens of millions?" and if the answer is hundreds or more and you're still trying to find that sucking sound, you're an ex-growth company.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A concrete signal combining valuation expectations with lack of customer pull to identify “ex-growth” risk.

quotes.topic_title: Ex-growth companies: definition, risks, and signals
quotes.text: So that's the reason why I tend to feel like you can kind of tell by how hard it is to acquire your users.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A practical PMF heuristic: acquisition difficulty as an early indicator before the “mathy” metrics stabilize.

quotes.topic_title: Ex-growth companies: definition, risks, and signals
quotes.text: When companies are putting very little in marketing and there're people coming into the door or there's such an easy sale, you've got it.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A memorable rule-of-thumb for recognizing strong product pull and likely product-market fit.

quotes.topic_title: Ex-growth companies: definition, risks, and signals
quotes.text: But the learning position, the loyalty tend to be the primary reasons to maybe delay the decision, but fear of finding another job is a bad reason, but is an often common reason as well.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Counterintuitive career advice on when staying can make sense—and a common but flawed rationale for not leaving.

quotes.topic_title: Early PMs: pick a lane and craft your story
quotes.text: There's probably two answers that I would share. One is, they want to build something that they as much as possible are world-class in.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Sets a clear early-career goal: deliberately develop a standout strength rather than being average across everything.

quotes.topic_title: Early PMs: pick a lane and craft your story
quotes.text: So, being a product manager means you're confronted with maybe all five or maybe more of these. I want to know that you pick up one of these as early as possible.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A practical framework for early PM development: choose one dimension of ambiguity to master early.

quotes.topic_title: Early PMs: pick a lane and craft your story
quotes.text: But picking a lane is kind of goal number one. And then maybe goal number two is having a story to tell to that next employer and that next, next.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Provides a two-part career strategy: specialize, then craft a coherent narrative of impact and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Early PMs: pick a lane and craft your story
quotes.text: So it's just like Amazon talks about building the press release before they start creating a product. Think about the story, think about the skill, then solve your day to day, your week to week, your month to month, your performance review.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A memorable methodology: reverse-engineer your career moves from the story/skills you want to be able to credibly tell later.

quotes.topic_title: Mid-career promotions: four common blockers
quotes.text: I think that the answer of what you do is correlated with what's the real reason. And I think that there may be, I'll suggest four kind of common things I've seen that really hold people back.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Sets up a diagnostic approach: identify the true cause before choosing a promotion strategy, framed as four common blockers.

quotes.topic_title: Mid-career promotions: four common blockers
quotes.text: So I think the number one is that you just don't have advocacy. You need someone to see the magic in you to be promoted.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Highlights advocacy as a prerequisite for promotion, shifting focus from performance alone to sponsorship and visibility.

quotes.topic_title: Mid-career promotions: four common blockers
quotes.text: I think the second that's very common now, Lenny, and I think it's coming up a ton, is the next role doesn't exist.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A counterintuitive blocker: you can be qualified and performing at the next level, but structural constraints can still prevent promotion.

quotes.topic_title: Mid-career promotions: four common blockers
quotes.text: And then they get frustrated when they can't do that, and leadership takes longer to absorb. It's more soft skills, it's more subtle. Oftentimes it's based on impact, which is a lot of times lagging, and that tends to be frustrating.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Explains why promotion timelines often slow in leadership roles and what changes (soft skills, lagging impact) practitioners should plan for.

quotes.topic_title: Mid-career promotions: four common blockers
quotes.text: And then the fourth one I think is about 50% of the cases where it's really, there is a development area but it isn't quite connected to the individual.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Provides a concrete prevalence estimate and points to self-awareness gaps as a major, often-missed promotion blocker.

quotes.topic_title: Getting real feedback and building feedback safety
quotes.text: The cheap answer is you have to get real feedback, not formal feedback.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A clear directive to prioritize candid, informal feedback over official performance systems to find the real signal.

quotes.topic_title: Getting real feedback and building feedback safety
quotes.text: But honestly, we've run experiments where we said let's ignore the formal feedback, let's have a real conversation with my peers on how our teams are doing. The signal that comes out are dramatically different than the formal feedback.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A concrete example showing that peer “ground truth” can diverge sharply from formal feedback mechanisms.

quotes.topic_title: Getting real feedback and building feedback safety
quotes.text: You have to triangulate it from people that don't see you all the time, that do see you all the time, your peers.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A practical methodology for increasing feedback accuracy by sampling multiple perspectives with different exposure to your work.

quotes.topic_title: Getting real feedback and building feedback safety
quotes.text: I think that the one that even ones up it is, when I talk to Jules, Jules will look for feedback, then he'll repeat it back to me better than even I presented it.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A memorable technique for building feedback safety: restate feedback so clearly the giver feels understood and encouraged to share more.

quotes.topic_title: Getting real feedback and building feedback safety
quotes.text: The next Monday when I have my staff meeting, I'll make a comment about something and I'll say, "Well, lot of this came because I got this great piece of feedback from..." and I'll name the person, and I'm like, "It really helped me see this challenge."
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: An actionable tactic to incentivize candid feedback by publicly crediting people who give it, reducing the social barrier to speaking up.

quotes.topic_title: Why managers struggle and how new managers succeed
quotes.text: I'll start by saying that, in a hundred years when the archeologists look back and they see tech in the sort of early years of tech, the first 34 years, they'll say that the biggest surprise was how much we thought it was okay to not train managers.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A contrarian diagnosis of why management quality is often poor in tech: the industry systematically under-trains managers.

quotes.topic_title: Why managers struggle and how new managers succeed
quotes.text: I think that there's such a loose coupling between the skills to be successful at building things and teaching people how to build. It's the difference between if you can make a good car, you must know how to make the factory that makes the car. I don't think that's true at all.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A memorable analogy that reframes the common promotion fallacy: being great at execution doesn’t imply being great at leading others.

quotes.topic_title: Why managers struggle and how new managers succeed
quotes.text: One is, your challenge is going to be to share the steering wheel with the person or the set of people you are managing.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A practical north star for new managers: success hinges on co-ownership rather than control or delegation-by-abdication.

quotes.topic_title: Why managers struggle and how new managers succeed
quotes.text: I think it's more like the sidecar on the motorcycle, where person's driving the motorcycle and I'm on the sidecar and whether I like it or not, I'm attached, but I have this relatively specific role of giving counsel.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A concrete mental model (“sidecar”) for how managers should stay connected while letting the report drive, focusing on counsel and shared responsibility.

quotes.topic_title: Why managers struggle and how new managers succeed
quotes.text: And what I find is that you're more like the vampire knocking on the door of someone. You have to be invited in. You just can't walk through the threshold.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance for earning trust: managerial authority isn’t enough—you need explicit permission to engage in specific areas.

quotes.topic_title: Senior IC path: why it’s growing and valuable
quotes.text: So I think Lenny, to your question, I think the IC track is one of the best things that's going to happen for people career. But to your point, those tracks, from a promotion and from a industry, how we perceive it, they're not in cement yet. They're tender. You wait six months, you wait nine months, they'll become very, very strong and solid. And I think then, we'll be able to lean very hard into them as a real promising crack for builders.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Frames the senior IC path as a near-term, strengthening career option and suggests timing expectations for practitioners betting on it.

quotes.topic_title: Senior IC path: why it’s growing and valuable
quotes.text: So I actually think it's a bug that has existed for a long time that actually we're going to correct permanently now.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A contrarian mental model: the PM-to-management default is an industry “bug,” and the IC track is the durable correction.

quotes.topic_title: Senior IC path: why it’s growing and valuable
quotes.text: My hard part is actually cracking the code on this complex market or this very complicated organization where we have two teams that have different goals. You're the type of person I want.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Clarifies what senior ICs can uniquely optimize for—solving complex market/org problems—versus “managing ambiguity” as a generic skill.

quotes.topic_title: Senior IC path: why it’s growing and valuable
quotes.text: But a lot of your listeners like to build. And actually, when they talk to their managers, they're like, "I don't know if that job is awesome. It feels like you spend all your time writing docs and telling your boss's boss what to justify resources and headcount. I just want to build stuff. You don't build stuff."
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: A vivid, practical check for choosing IC vs management: compare day-to-day work (building) against management’s resource-justification overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern grow team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical gap teams face: experimentation is mandatory, but tooling often doesn’t fit modern growth workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to waste of time building internal tools or trying to run your own experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Calls out a common operational failure mode that practitioners can watch for and proactively avoid.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic, click-through metrics and instead use your North Star metrics like activation, retention, subscription, and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear measurement framework: optimize experiments around North Star metrics rather than shallow engagement metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo supports test on the front end, on the back end, email marketing, even machine learning claims.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Expands the experimentation methodology beyond UI tests, suggesting a broader surface area for rigorous testing.

quotes.topic_title: Community as the missing manager training layer
quotes.text: I think community as a way of creating safety, having authentic conversations, feeling that you're not alone, that others are going through the same thing, and then sharing best practices is so powerful.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Frames community as the missing layer for management development by combining psychological safety, shared experience, and practical knowledge transfer.

quotes.topic_title: Community as the missing manager training layer
quotes.text: I think that all of your listeners should be part of an active community where they can be very authentic and very safe. Sometimes it's hard to do that with your coworkers, and so you need to find another community.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Actionable advice to deliberately seek (or create) a safe peer community—especially when internal dynamics prevent candor.

quotes.topic_title: Community as the missing manager training layer
quotes.text: What you realize is, it's a very lonely job. Being lonely at the top is not just an adage. Really, everyone's so busy now. It's like, how do you have time to connect? Everything's a single player, you don't really have community.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Diagnoses the root problem communities solve: leadership roles become isolating “single player” experiences without intentional connection.

quotes.topic_title: Community as the missing manager training layer
quotes.text: And we started to connect and we built this trust, and community building is interesting and powerful work. So six went to 12, and then 12 went to 15, and now we have 28 members. A lot of folks are interested in these types of communities, but I'm so worried about scaling it because it's the enemy of trust and authenticity.
quotes.speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
quotes.context: Concrete scaling example plus a counterintuitive warning: growth can undermine the trust and authenticity that make communities valuable.
